details.title: Improvement on “Sequential Testing” in MIL-HDBK-781A and IEC 61124

authors.affiliation: Fac. of Ind. & Manage. Eng., Technion Israel Inst. of Technol, Haifa

p: Yefim Haim Michlin is a Senior Researcher in Quality Assurance and Reliability at the Technion—Israel Institute of Technology. He obtained the Ph.D. (1980) in statistical dynamics of machines. He worked from 1973 to 1990 at the Tashkent State Polytechnic University (Associate Professor). Since 1991, he has been teaching at the Technion (Reliability Engineering and Management). He is a Senior Member of the IEEE Reliability Society.

authors.name: Yefim Haim Michlin

p: Lyubov Meshkov received the M.Sc. In Electrical Engineering in 1993, and is now a student working towards the M.Sc. degree, in Quality Assurance and Reliability, at the Technion (final stage).

Irit Grunin received the B.Sc. In Information Measurement Engineering in 1998, and the M.Sc. In Quality Assurance and Reliability, Technion in 2006. His present occupation is the Quality Assurance Responsible Person at Plasson Ltd.

details.abstract: This paper presents results of an analysis of the sequential test (ST) procedures described in MIL-HDBK-781A, and IEC 61124, intended for checking the mean Time Between Failures (TBF) value under an exponential distribution of the TBF. The methodological basis of the calculations consists in discretization of the ST process through subdivision of the time axis in small segments. By this means, the process is converted into a binomial for which an algorithm, and a fast computer program have been developed; and most important of all, a tool is provided for searching for the optimal truncation. The influence of truncation by time on the Expected Test Time (ETT) characteristics was studied; and an improved truncation method, minimizing this influence, was developed. The distributions of the test times were determined. The type A plan characteristics in IEC 61124:2006 have substantial inconsistencies in the probabilities of types I & II errors (up to a factor of 2), and in the ETT (up to 17%). We checked these results by using the binomial-recursive method, and by simulation. The Type C plans, reproduced from GOST R27.402:2005, are consistent; but there is scope (and need) for substantial improvement of the search algorithm for the optimal parameters.

Check of plan characteristics in [3].

The proposed procedure as per Section II-C was used for checking the characteristics of the Type A plans in [3], Table 2; in all of them, errors were found in \$\alpha\$, and \$\beta\$, ranging from 5% to 104%.
Matching of the calculated ETT for \$\theta\$ to the [3] data also showed discrepancies in all nine tests, ranging from 0.6% to 17%.

In [3], the original series was supplemented by eight sequential tests of type C whose boundaries are likewise oblique straight lines, with truncation by number of failures (max \$r_{0}\$), and by test time \$(T_{0})\$.
We determined them for all eight tests as per [3], Table 2 using the binomial approach, and found complete agreement with the above table.
Annex K.4 to [3] presents an iterative procedure for choosing the boundaries, with the stipulation that optimality is associated with a minimal ETT.

Two further drawbacks are (a) no algorithm is provided for choosing the plan parameters, only a recommendation that they be varied until an optimum is reached; or (b) cumbrousness of the formulae, actually remarked upon in the text [3], Annex K, p. 247.
As noted earlier (Section I), the truncation choice methodology (choice of \$r_{0}\$) presented in [1], and repeated in [2], [3], has significant advantages.
This in turn permits better grounding in the choice of the latter, as against the approach recommended in [1], and [3] (Type A, and C Plans).
The Type A plan characteristics in [3] have substantial errors in \$\alpha\$ and \$\beta\$ (up to 104%), and in the ETT (up to 17%).
The Type C plans in [3], reproduced from GOST R27.402:2005 [26], are error-free; but there is scope (and need) for substantial improvement of the search algorithm for the optimal parameters.
